results.abstract: Board set up to review construction of spaceship to return astronauts to Moon is loaded with employees of contractors it is supposed to scrutinize; NASA inspector general recommends suspending 6 of 19 board members, including chairman and former astronaut Ed Gibson (S)
results.snippet: A board set up to review construction of the spaceship to return astronauts to the Moon is loaded with employees of the contractors it is  supposed to scrutinize, breaking federal law, a government watchdog says. The board chairman, Ed Gibson, a...
results.lead_paragraph: A board set up to review construction of the spaceship to return astronauts to the Moon is loaded with employees of the contractors it is supposed to scrutinize, breaking federal law, a government watchdog says. The board chairman, Ed Gibson, a former Skylab astronaut, and five other members work for companies hired by NASA on the multibillion-dollar space shuttle replacement program. The NASA inspector general, the agency's in-house watchdog, calls that a conflict of interest and recommends suspending the six board members. The board has 19 members. NASA contends that in the specialized field of aerospace, most of the experts work for either NASA or its contractors. Plans call for astronauts to return to the Moon by 2020.

results.abstract: Democratic presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton does not dare to take day of rest on Mother's Day, instead spending 16-hour day slogging through rain to campaign with daughter Chelsea in West Virginia; hopes to win over mothers who see in her chance to break through ultimate glass ceiling, though her prospects of becoming Democratic nominee appear more of long shot; photos (M)

headline.main: As Rivals Rest on Mother's Day, Clinton Pushes On

results.snippet: No breakfast in bed for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: She rose early and spent a 16-hour day slogging through a cold rain in West Virginia.
results.lead_paragraph: On Mother's Day, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was not served breakfast in bed. She did not go to a fancy lunch, or get to be queen for a day. Instead, she rose early and spent a 16-hour day slogging through a cold rain in West Virginia, the next state on her to-do list.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students infer the meaning and significance of an article on the Mars Lander using vocabulary words. They then write and draw a comic book that depicts a related science concept, based in part on further research, designed for younger readers.

headline.main: Human Guinea Pig Seeking Cure for Jet Lag

results.snippet: This weekend, we're running an article called "Coffee and naps not helping your jet lag? Try starving instead." The snappy headline (thanks to yours truly, ahem), is not totally straightforward. If you read into the text from Reuters, it quotes a...
results.lead_paragraph: This weekend, we're running an article called "Coffee and naps not helping your jet lag? Try starving instead." The snappy headline (thanks to yours truly, ahem), is not totally straightforward. If you read into the text from Reuters, it quotes a study showing that food deprivation, or a drastic change in meal times, can override a mouse's internal clock and its natural mechanism for coordinating waking and sleeping with periods of light and dark. "A period of fasting with no food at all for about 16 hours is enough to engage this new clock," said Dr. Clifford Saper of Harvard Medical School, whose study appears in Science.

results.abstract: Mike Myer Letter From Beijing notes that with Olympic Games approaching, China is undertaking effort to have 35 percent of population conversant in English; is using cartoon monkey popularized in elementary school language textbook series; drawing (M)
results.snippet: With the Games approaching, a question: Can an irritating monkey help China become conversant in English?
results.lead_paragraph: Mocky is a naughty monkey. His friends Ken and Ann are humans. Together, they teach English in Beijing's elementary schools. My students love Mocky. He and his pals are more fun than the characters in their previous textbook series, Ma Nan and her teacher Miss Zhang. Those primers could have been titled ''Hectoring English.'' A typical dialogue went: ''You're late again, Ma Nan.''

headline.main: Shuttle on Schedule for Saturday Launch

results.snippet: The shuttle Discovery is scheduled to blast off at 5:02 Saturday afternoon. Its cargo includes an all important unit needed to repair the malfunctioning toilet.
results.lead_paragraph: Both weather and technology seem to be cooperating for launching the space shuttle Discovery on Saturday to begin a mission to the International Space Station. The shuttle, with its crew of seven astronauts, is scheduled to blast off at 5:02 Saturday afternoon to bring a tour-bus-sized science laboratory to the station, the $1 billion ''Kibo'' module. Kathy Winters, a weather officer with the 45th Weather Squadron of the Air Force, announced at a morning briefing with reporters on Friday that the probability that weather conditions would be favorable for launch at an unusually high 80 percent. ''The weather is looking promising,'' she said, but added that if technical issues cause a delay, conditions will worsen over the next two days. No technical glitches with the vehicle have emerged.

results.snippet: INTERACTIVE: DETAILED LOOK AT CRANE ACCIDENT     Details on the latest fatal crane accident in New York, including a video of construction workers at the Upper East Side site, a diagram outlining the sequence of events, a graphic locating other New...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERACTIVE: DETAILED LOOK AT CRANE ACCIDENT Details on the latest fatal crane accident in New York, including a video of construction workers at the Upper East Side site, a diagram outlining the sequence of events, a graphic locating other New York construction sites where crane violations have been cited, reactions of witnesses in the neighborhood and photographs submitted by readers.
